ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Overall great class. Guest speakers were a little outside of the focus though.

I know it's a survey course, but I still wish that it was a bit more practical and in-depth. Having assignments that required us to do financial models or analyze legal contracts would have been very useful for me
N/A
I was auditing the course.
7b- The TAs for this course wereoutstanding.

It was great to have the opportunity to work on a problem of our own choosing, as opposed to having to work on problems not as relevant to our intended career. This makes the work more enjoyable, engaging, and useful. Overall, we covered a great deal of material and I think the course is well tailored for its intended audience of FES students. Students from SOM or YLS might find they know a good proportion of the concepts already, but they can deepen their knowledge in the desired areas.

My only issue with this class is that I can't see the point of going to a class where I can learn everything by reading slides later. It seems more efficient to just stay home and do the reading and read the slides--but it becomes a political thing to make an appearance. This is a problem I have with many FES classes. Homework and class instruction need to each separate value and simply reviewing slides (even while they're great slides!) doesn't do it.

This was a great class that covers the overlap of environmental policy, business, and law that is often overlooked in the curriculum. Professor Gentry presented the material in a very clear manner and provided many examples that resonated with the students, regardless of their interests. The TAs were also helpful in making themselves available and providing guidance on the midterm and final.
Brad is a fantastic professor. He crafts the semester very coherently, his lectures are engaging and relevant, and he chooses excellent guest lecturers. This has been my favorite class at FES.
The practical nature of the course. We learned useful tools that will aid in the next steps of my professional career.
Good clear instruction from Professor Gentry.
I really appreciated the fact that the assignments were entirely focused on an issue of importance to us - this made it all seem worthwhile.
The breadth of tools covered, and the clear level of knowledge the professor had about those various tools
Well-structured; systematic; covered a wide range of topics, managed to link different topics in a relevant way; knowledgeable professor; interesting outside lecturers
I was an auditor but enjoyed both the readings and the lectures.
Professor Gentry is an excellent lecturer. The guest speakers were also great and added a nice perspective.

Provided a nice, consolidated summary of the various legal/investment concepts that were familiar, but I didn't necessarily know the details of. It gave me a reason to really think through in more depth some issues that I had thought about only vaguely before.
The breadth of the concepts covered

Brad Gentry is phenomenal teacher-- perhaps because he has real life experience and isn't a professor bogged down in research. The readings for the class were great, but there was way too much of it. We were assigned an impossible amount of reading for the class each week. I know each reading was useful, but Gentry might want to consider cutting down the amount as it's too daunting to try and keep on top of it.
Ability to work on a self-selected problem, exceptional lecturing skills of faculty, availability of TA's for questions, great guest lecturers that added to the discussion.
Chance to write an interesting paper on a topic of your choice
The material was totally relevant to MEM students. I loved the syllabus and Professor Gentry's approachability was wonderful.

My favorite part of the class was applying all tools we learned in class to a particular problem of interest to each student. It was challenging, but really made me think about the complexities of applying each tool.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I wish the professor was made more accessible to students as a resource. It would have been nice if he had special office hours available to us.I wish that there were more international issues covered in the class.

I think the homework could be improved, to have more regular due dates for assignments. There should be a better way for engaging the students with the reading, and for having more open discussion of how students are applying the concepts to their papers. Presentations of topics would have been interesting/fun interactive component to add to class.
I think the course might benefit from a case study approach, where we could really dig into why different tools do and don't work in various circumstances
Be more specific on how to apply the tools studied in class; provide more examples of applications

I think sometimes the lectures spent a lot of time covering topics that for me were fairly basic and already familiar (ie, the basics of property transactions). Speeding through those a bit quicker to spend more time on some of the detailed issues relating to environmental topics might help.
Too many powerpoint slides!
The amount of reading-- see above.

Overall great course. The only thing I would add is that the course would benefit from adding perhaps one more (formal) small assignment/problem like for example the problem that Bryan Garcia shared with the class, or something on that order of simplicity/complexity. Ideally it could be some short essay or problem set on a real world applied issue, just to drive a given lesson home. I think that would be useful, but I think it should be only a small assignment representing a small part of the grade, so as to not distract from the principal project the student is focusing on.
A way to hold students more accountable for the reading would have been great. Discussion sections or time for more questions in class would have been great.
I don't think the class needs to be improved.

Always hard to teach a survey class - I wanted more on many of the topics and less on some of them. I'm not sure how to offer that, and the lead-up process to the final paper certainly does try. Just something to keep in mind for offering more options for independent study within the class.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Professor Gentry was very open and willing to meet with students and discuss their particular interests.
Very good availability from TAs.
Very available, good assistance from TAs and professor.
Yoni Cohen - did a great job answering my questions about both the midterm and the final - really engaged with me and helped me work through my ideas.
Didn't really seek them out
N/A
The instructor was very responsive given that I was an auditor.
Excellent.
They always seemed accessible, but I never went to office hours.
Gentry was pretty accessible and the TAs were all fantastic and offered an unprecedented amount of office hours and help. Great team.
I didn't go to office hours or ask many out-of-class questions, but I always felt the faculty and TA's were responsive and very available.
All excellent. The TAs definitely contributed to my experience.
I did not seek assistance from the professor or TA, but they all seemed to be available for any questions or to talk through the students' papers.
Didn't really take advantage.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Great way to bring together students with interests in business, law, and environment.
This class fit very nicely with helping me to pursue my overall interests this semester.
Helped me gain some knowledge about legal practices and tools; added to my existing finance experience

I wish I had taken this my first year, because I think it would have been helpful to take early on. That said, it fit in very well with other classes I've taken about green technology financing, energy economics, and other classes that generally try to get students to think about how to get private actors involved in better environmental management.
It was very relevant to what I want to do. A very important and interesting class that I think can help anyone at FES understand and pursue their career goals better.

I have an interest in energy policy and so this course will help me consider all of the legal tools available in addressing a given issue. It also provided me useful frameworks within which to organize those tools.
This course was incredibly helpful for looking at the environmental problem in which I am interested from a different perspective.
I plan to focus on policies that promote private investment, so this was an essential class for my curriculum.
I am interested in the politics of business action on climate solutions, so this course fits my focus perfectly.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I found the toolbox nature of the course to be very valuable and interesting.
Fulfill a degree requirement.
To build out my toolbox w/regards to different public/private mechanisms that could spur private investment in the environment
Thought it might be helpful and bring some diversity to my courses
I audited it - wanted literacy that parts of the course provided.
I audited this course in order to gain exposure to the material.
Wanted to think through private investment concepts more fully -- get a better understanding of terminology and specific tools.
Wanted a basic understanding of private investment tools
Because it relates directly to what I want to do.
The content seems relevant and I enjoy Brad's style of teaching.
I knew that it would be useful.
I plan to focus on policies that promote private investment, so this was an essential class for my curriculum.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: A bit of review but in a good way.
Yes
Exceeded my expectations.
I feel like I got exposure to a number of tools, but I don't feel like it was a skill-building class in the way I might have hoped
In a sense - was a bit too theoretical sometimes
Yes : I gained a lot from the classes I went to and the readings I did.
Absolutely- it was great.
Yes.
For the most part but the class would benefit from some group projects or in-class small group discussions
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, the course was great. I regret not asking more questions and really trying to get everything out of it.
Yes, it met all of my expectations.
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Somewhat. Again, more pragmatic applications to real world circumstances, with assignments geared towards those cases, would be nice
ALmost
Yes. Same as above.
yes.
yes.
yes.
Yes.
Yes
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Might have been nice to work in a group where members were all interested in the same issues to discuss and compare different legal and financial tools.

Group work = collaborating and discussing paper topics with other students. It was critical to have an opportunity to talk with other students about how to apply the theories, and I would recommend more structured labsessions to facilitate those discussions for future semesters.
N/A
N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be open to learning new ideas.
Enjoy the process of thinking about a problem that you care about.
Choose a topic that you really do care about and want to work on in the future - it makes the assignments very interesting and enjoyable.
Best as an intro survey course -- take it as a primer for future work, not as a skill-building class
Work early and consistently on your term paper. Will learn a lot.
N/A
Do some outside research on the speakers before they come- then you can ask better questions.

Try to look at the topics presented with a critical and creative eye for how they relate to topics you're interested in. If you're not always trying to relate the concepts back to something you care about, the lectures might seem a bit dull.
Take this course. Gentry is going to be one of the best lecturers you'll ever have at FES.

There is a lot of available material/readings. You will definitely NOT be able to read it all, but focus on the most pertinent and important readings for each lecture. And mark the ones you're not able to read so you can get to them later... they are great readings.
Ask a lot of questions and at the very least, skim the readings.
Begin thinking about your chosen problem early and flag relevant lectures or slides throughout class for ideas that apply.
Sit up front so you can really pay attention - the info is worth it.
